Thomas Miller Mortuary & Crematory: A Compassionate Funeral Home in Corona, CA

Located at 1118 E. 6th St., Corona, CA, 92879, Thomas Miller Mortuary & Crematory is a trusted and compassionate funeral home that has been serving the community for years. With a commitment to providing exceptional service and care, this mortuary has established itself as a beacon of hope and support during difficult times.

A Legacy of Excellence

Thomas Miller Mortuary & Crematory has built a reputation for excellence by providing personalized and dignified funeral services to families in need. Their experienced team of funeral directors, embalmers, and support staff are dedicated to ensuring that every family receives the highest level of care and attention to detail. From traditional funeral services to cremations and memorial ceremonies, this mortuary offers a range of options to suit individual needs and preferences.

Thomas Miller Mortuary & Crematory

Address: 1118 E. 6th St., Corona, CA, 92879

Phone Number: (951) 737-3244

Get Direction: Google Maps Link

Jesus C Espinoza - August 06, 1968 - May 15, 2024

Departed: 05/15/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: Jesse Espinoza was born August 6, 1968, in San Diego, California. At the age of one he came to live in Corona, Ca. Jesse is preceded in death by his father Pedro Espinoza. He is survived by his mother Dolores Espinoza, of Corona, Ca., and his son Christopher, along with his four siblings: Pete & Maria Espinoza, Sylvia Logan, Refugio (Cuca) Espinoza, and Martin & Michelle Espinoza. Jesse is also survived by many nieces and nephews: Pete & Carissa Espinoza, Vanessa & Jesus Madriz, Martin & Vivian Espinoza, Crystal & Jose Medina, Shaylee Logan, and Montana & Cory Kienzle. Jesse had fun alongside all his great nieces and nephews: Savannah, Martin Jr., Jeremiah, Sophia, Sadie, Matthew, Pete IV, Bethany, Jacob, Malia, Mylah, Camila, and Sienna. He was loved by many relatives and friends. As you know Jesse could light up any room with his sense of humor of making everyone laugh and he could start a dancefloor anytime and anywhere. He loved the Angels and Rams, and he was faithful to his teams whether they won or lost. We will miss you so much Father, Son, Brother, Uncle, Cousin, and Friend but this is not a goodbye but a see you later. We love you; may you now rest peacefully in the arms of Jesus.

View Full Obituary

Maria Guadalupe Espinosa - December 12, 1942 - May 14, 2024

Departed: 05/14/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: Maria Guadalupe "Lupe" Espinosa, 81 years of age of Corona, California, passed away on the 14th of May 2024 at Riverside Community Hospital with her loving family at her bedside. Lupe was born on 12th of December 1942, in Abasolo, Guanajuato, Mexico and was one of six children. On March 24, 1962 she married Luis Espinosa and went on to have nine children, many grandchildren, and even some great-grandchildren. They were married for almost 60 years prior to Luis' passing in 2022. Lupe was a devoted wife, mother, and grandmother; and a committed homemaker that served her family selflessly throughout her life. She lived a fearless life guided by her faith and her love for family and friends. She left her home in Mexico and raised her family in a country where she learned to adapt to the new language (even though she never quite learned it) and a new way of life filled with challenges and obstacles. Despite this, she was the solid foundation upon which her family rested. Everyone that met her or knew her was, in some way, touched and changed by her unconditional love and wisdom, or her food. Whether she was cooking in it or teaching those willing to learn, her kitchen was her and everyone's favorite place, and a good meal was her way of saying "thank you" or "hello." Although she was many things to many people, she would like to be remembered as a woman of unwavering faith in Jesus Christ, which she would enthusiastically share with anyone willing to listen, and even some that weren't.

Jack William Kroonen - May 14, 1930 - May 02, 2024

Departed: 05/02/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: Jack William Kroonen, 93 passed away on May 2, 2024 in Corona, CA. He was born on May 14, 1930 in Long Beach, CA to William and Stella Kroonen. Shortly after his birth, the family moved to Corona, CA where he attended school and graduated from Corona Senior High School in 1948. He attended Cal Poly State University-San Luis Obispo for one year. Realizing he spent more time playing golf than attending classes he decided not to return. While attending the Pomona Fair in the summer of 1949, he spoke to a recruiter, and joined the Marines within days. While stationed in Quantico, Virginia he met Elaine (Cunliffe-Owen) Kroonen. They were married on April 15, 1953, and had celebrated 70 years of marriage in 2023. After serving our country, he went on to work for Douglas Aircraft. During this time, he was offered an opportunity to work in England on the largest radio telescope. Jack and Elaine took this opportunity to travel all through Europe. They settled in Corona, CA in 1971 and became business owners. They owned Ace Hardware and Ace Lawnmower, along with Fares Industrial Supply until his retirement in 1998. He was a quiet and humble man, never wanting anyone to fuss over him. He loved his sweetheart and was the main caregiver in the last few years of her life. His love for golf started when his dad introduced him to the game when he was 11 years old. He was a member of different golf clubs and golfed at Jarupa Hills for many years. He loved to travel in their motorhome across the country, visiting every state and of course golfing. They had many fun memories with their Boat and Ski club and was a long time member of the Elks. He was a father figure to his nephew David and niece Erika and a Papa to Emmett, Grant and Sofie. Always having his family over for dinner and swimming, not to mention all the ice cream and desserts. Jack is survived by his nephew David (Erika) Cunliffe-Owen, great nephews and niece, Emmett, Grant and Sofia Cunliffe-Owen; sister-in-law Beverly (Ron) Cunliffe-Owen; sister-in-law Carol (Bob) Kolb; brother-in-law Phil (Susan) Cunliffe-Owen; sister-in-law Jeannie Truax; Godsons, Todd, Michael, and Paul Guirsch. He is preceded in death by his wife Elaine (Cunliffe-Owen) Kroonen; father William Kroonen; mother Stella (Kroonen) Starr; his many Boston Terriers and extended family and friends. David and Erika would like to extend a special thank you to Doug and Carleen Sigsbee for their love, care, and being his advocate, always willing to step in and help when we couldn’t. We appreciate you. To honor his wishes, there will be no service.

Justin Riley Pagán Brown - October 24, 1997 - April 24, 2024

Departed: 04/24/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: Justin Riley Pagán-Brown was born in Whittier, California on October 24, 1997, to Michelle Pagán-Aguiar and Ronald Kevin Brown. He died at the age of 26 on April 24, 2024. Justin unconditionally loved his family, friends, and Gabby, his Jack Russell Terrier. Justin grew up in Corona, California. He had a passion for collecting spiders from a young age and was fascinated by them. This drove his kindergarten teacher crazy as he would rally other boys during recess to collect spiders with him and bring them back into the classroom in their sandwich bags. As an adult, Justin still laughed about that. He loved going to school and learning. Justin attended Citrus Hills Intermediate and found a passion for acting. He played a role in Scrooge his first year, which took him and his drama class to perform in downtown Riverside during Christmas. He then played a role in Grease. In sixth grade Justin and his good friend Tanner Ralls won the science fair. They went on to the County competition and also won. Again, they moved on to the state competition for their project in engineering relating to rust prevention and received honorable mention being so young. Justin never missed a day of school until a football injury his senior year. Justin played catcher, center field and outfield in little league. He tried his hand at basketball as well and loved that sport until he was introduced to football. He started playing for the Corona Chargers Junior League and they were champions three years in a row. He couldn’t wait for high school football. While in high school at Santiago he was an excellent student and in AP classes. He was able to manage a tough schedule with football and homework. Justin was a varsity letterman in Santiago football, and he loved being a running back. He worked out like crazy and gave his all at practice and games. He was one of the strongest kids on his team and excelled at weightlifting. Justin loved watching the TV show “The Office” and thought that was one of the funniest shows. He enjoyed riding dirt bikes and learned at a young age. Some of the many family camping trips and Santiago High School family trips were to Ocotillo Wells, Gorman, Calico, and the Lake Elsinore track. He loved going to Havasu and the Parker Strip during the summer and enjoyed wakeboarding, tubing and heading out on the wave-runners. He loved being on and in the water. Justin quickly learned to love going on cruises and went to the Caribbean twice with his mom. He loved the island life and had another trip planned for September 2024, to visit Oahu. Justin went on many trips with his mom and his friends where he spent a lot of time fishing and enjoying all the amenities the resorts had to offer. He loved room service and thought that was the neatest thing. Justin also went on many father and son road trips; like snowmobiling in Yellowstone National Park, backpacking Sequoia National Park, and snow skiing in Montana. He loved rollercoasters and visited Cedar Point Amusement Park and then from there he and his father went on to Niagara Falls in New York. Another highlight was a high school football father-son rafting trip on the Merced River. All these adventures led him to taking a backpacking trip with friends in the Sierras. On the way to college at Washington State University, Justin and his father stopped in Seattle for horseback riding, the Duck Tour and enjoyed all the local sights. Justin’s last trip was to Pittsburg. His father surprised him for his birthday and they went to see the Pittsburg Steelers, which was his favorite football team. Justin had a lot of good memories to share from that trip. Justin was preceded in death by Paternal Grandparents, Clifford and Margaret Brown and Aunt, Jaqueline Robinson. Justin is survived by Mother, Michelle Pagán; Father, Ronald Brown (Wife, Jessie Brown), Maternal Grandparents, Roger and Mary Weber; Paternal Uncles, Kenny Brown and Randy Brown; Maternal Uncles, Paul Pagán, William DiMartino, Mark Criddle; Maternal Aunts, Maureen DiMartino and Glory Criddle; Paternal Aunt, Edith Lloyd; Maternal Cousins Ryan and Jessie DiMartino, and Bryce and Hunter Criddle; and loved by many cousins and extended family in Chicago and Louisiana.

Rex Scott - September 26, 1938 - April 18, 2024

Departed: 04/18/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: Rex Ronald Scott Sunrise: September 26, 1938 Sunset: April 18, 2024 Rex R. Scott of Hemet, California passed away on April 18, 2024 peacefully at his home. Rex was born in Bristol, Nebraska to the late Irene Leah Carr and Robert Byron Scott. Rex married Mary Lou Blaski after their 3rd date on March 25, 1963 in Roberts, South Dakota. With their union, they had two son’s: Richard and Tracy. Rex was Honorably discharged from the United States Air force in 1963. He worked for 30 years in the Sheet Metal Industry. He was a member of the Knights of Columbus #5528 and Norwalk Elks Lodge #2142. Rex was preceded in death by his wife, Mary Lou; son, Richard; his brother, Floyd; his sister, Roberta. He leaves behind is son Tracy and his wife Robyn; His sister Estella and her husband Charles; His brother Claude and his wife Ann; His grandchildren Christopher and honored granddaughter Lilly; Elena, Cindy Hitt and Robin Graham. His great-grandchildren Bryson, Rex 2nd, and Azalea. His trusted friend and neighbor, Barbara Silvers. Robyn and I would like to thank the Knights of Columbus, especially Bob McNallen, Mike Rathbone and John Pape for all their support, assistance and guidance. We would like to thank everyone that called, stopped by and sent messages.

Fabian Laureano Diaz Jr. - August 28, 1970 - April 08, 2024

Departed: 04/08/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: Fabian L Diaz Jr “Gordo” was born August 28, 1970 in Riverside, CA to Fabian Sr. and the late Mary Lou Cabrales Diaz. Fabian sadly passed away Monday, April 8, 2024 at the age of 53 at Kaiser Permanente of riverside . Fabian grew up in Imperial, CA where he attended Imperial High and participated in basketball and football. Fabian appeared in multiple front pages of the local newspaper for his outstanding performances on the varsity football team. Due to his hard work in and dedication on the football team, he recieved multiple college scholarships. Fabian moved to Corona, CA after graduating from high school where he later married his high school sweetheart Isabel. Three children were born from this union. Fabian was a parking attendant for the Pasadena Rose Bowl flea market for 10 years. There he worked along side his brother and cousins. Fabian always had them and anyone he’d meet there laughing and having a good time. Some of Fabian's favorite things to do included watching his favorite football team the Dallas Cowboys, enjoying time with family and friends, and jamming out to music. Fabian’s greatest joy was his family. He enjoyed spending time with his children and grandchildren. He also enjoyed cheering on his granddaughter Amaya during her softball games. Fabian is survived by his wife Isabel, his 3 children Adrian, Samantha and Marissa, his father Fabian Sr., and his siblings Jessica, Andy, and Alex. He was also a proud Tata to his four grandchildren Amaya, Nelson, Jordan, and Adrian Jr. Fabian was preceded in death by his beloved mother Mary Lou and baby brother George, father-in-law Camilo and brother-in-law Camilo Jr. Fabian was a loyal person to all who were lucky enough to make his acquaintance. He will truly be missed.

View Full Obituary

Zavier A Branch - November 18, 1994 - April 05, 2024

Departed: 04/05/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: I am sure that nothing can separate us from God's love—not life or death, not angels or spirits, not the present or the future, and not powers above or powers below. Nothing in all creation can separate us from God's love for us in Christ Jesus our Lord! Romans 8: 38-30 Zavier A. Branch was born on November 18, 1994, to the late Ron Branch and Cynthia Cooper- Branch in Orange County, California. April 5, 2024, marked the untimely passing of a remarkable, caring, and bright young soul. Zavier accepted Christ into his life at a very young age. He went on to join and attend Faith Fellowship Church while living in California. He became involved in several community youth groups in Corona. While attending La Sierra High School in Riverside, he participated in competitive gymnastics which afforded him the opportunity to travel and compete all over the United States. Following graduation in 2014, he mentored various community groups involved in gymnastics in developing their competitive skills. Upon graduation from High School, Zavier attended California State University Long Beach, studying Fashion and Merchandising. He worked through the ranks with several well-known retailers expanding his knowledge base, skills, experience, and business network. According to friends and business associates, he was a risk taker through and through and stopped at nothing to achieve the launch of his very own business. Zavier was confident in what he wanted and was relentless in pursuing it. ZB Home Company, LLC, with a focus on interior design, launched in the midst of the pandemic in 2020. His unique design approach was in such high demand, as evidenced by sales exceeding projections in the first two years. While ZB Home Company was based in San Antonio Texas, his expertise as an interior designer was in demand throughout the United States including California, New York, Florida, and Chicago. Zavier was a member of ASID (American Association of Interior Designers), as well as the San Antonio Chamber of Commerce. ZB Home Company was featured on several media platforms and local TV broadcasting including San Antonio Living and Home Sweet Home San Antonio. A two-page spread graced the Society Texas publication in 2022 highlighting his philosophy that interior design is to be “unique but livable”. Zavier’s accomplishments as an entrepreneur are worth the attention given as we celebrate his life as it’s a testament to how he lived his life regardless of the challenge he faced with having been diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes at the age of 3. This challenge did not slow him down, it only propelled him to relentlessly pursue his dreams. While being an amazing and successful entrepreneur, Zavier was foremost a family oriented young man. His presence during holidays, special occasions, and “just because—no reason” visits affirmed his love and commitment to family and friends. His love and compassion are seen throughout photos, videos, and social media. He touched each of us so deeply. There never was or ever will be a moment that a memory of him doesn’t bring a huge smile or crazy laugh to our hearts . His zest for life was contagious. Zavier’s desire for fun/adventure and to never stop learning, growing, and connecting with others took him to places like Mexico, Rome, Paris, Portugal and many other Get-Aways with family and friends. Zavier was preceded in death by his father Ronnie Branch, Sr. He is survived by his mother Cynthia Cooper-Branch of Corona, CA and two siblings Ronnie Branch of Riverside, CA and Veronica Branch of New Iberia, LA. Maternal grandparents: Proby Cooper and the late Jimmie Lou Cooper of Picayune, MS. Paternal grandparents: Dorothy Branch and the late James Branch, Sr of Picayune, MS. Surviving aunts include: Patricia Evans of Atlanta, GA, Sonji Cooper-Harris (Denver)of Riverside, CA, and Elice Johnson (Warren) of Camarillo, CA. Surviving uncle: Anthony Tolliver of Los Angeles, CA and one uncle, James Branch, Jr preceded him in death. He was also loving god-father to Ileana in California. Zavier is also survived by an extended family in San Antonio, Texas: Caleb Echols, LaRitta Webb, and Jessica Chiang and their families. He was known as “Tito” to Jessica’s children Ezra, Penelope and Eden. Often, Zavier spoke of how blessed he felt to have such loving and wonderful people to call family. He leaves with special memories a host of nieces, nephews, cousins, and many other family members. Countless friends in California, Texas and abroad, as Zavier touched so so many lives.

View Full Obituary

Pamela Ann Horvath - October 04, 1956 - April 03, 2024

Departed: 04/03/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: Pamela Ann Horvath, 67 of Corona, CA, passed away April 3rd, 2024 at her residence. She was an amazing woman and will be deeply missed by all who knew her and will live on in all our memories and experiences that we all shared. She leaves behind sons Casey and Jason Horvath; daughter in laws, Jen and Jeni Horvath; grandchildren; Amanda, her husband Brandon, Tyler, Lucas, Natalie, Noah, Logan, and Jackson in addition to great grandchildren Mila and Stevie. Lastly she leaves behind what became her trusted companion “Dixie”, her beloved dog. She was preceded in death by her husband Dennis, her parents Charles Calhoun and mother Gloria Martin, as well as her sister Sandy. Pam (Pamela) was born in Racine, Wisconsin on October 4th, 1956. She was the youngest of 3 to sisters Cindy and Sandy. Growing up in Wisconsin was hard at times though Pam thoroughly enjoyed being near so many cousins, aunts and uncles. However, in 1968, when she was 12, her family made the decision to head west to California for a brighter future and better weather. Unfortunately, their first stop ended up being in the Salton Sea. Her family spent three very long years there before moving to Anaheim in 1971. In Anaheim she finally embraced California and wasn’t homesick for Wisconsin. Pam worked at an early age from babysitting as soon as she could to waitressing. Pam enjoyed singing very much and performed at some local stadiums throughout her high school years. It was during her senior year of high school when she would meet her future husband Dennis, who was introduced to her by her father. Married in 1975, Pam and Dennis relocated to Corona, CA. Pam worked as a waitress at the local Denny’s restaurant while studying to earn her real estate license. In 1983, Pam and Dennis made the decision to purchase Hamner Towing Inc. This decision would shape much of the rest of her life as working a small business takes countless hours. The plan was for Pam to learn the books and then Dennis would then come over full time to run the business alongside her. As we all know that never really transpired, Dennis was doing well at the dealership and Pam was killing it as an owner of a towing company. Pam attacked everything with tenacity and hard work often sacrificing her own wishes to ensure the success of others and Hamner Towing. While Dennis was involved in every decision within the company it was Pam who was the heartbeat of what would become one of the most successful and trustworthy companies in the industry. Pam and Dennis decided to join various service clubs in the area and believed in supporting the community that supported them. Pam became the first woman to join the Norco Rotary Club. She would go on to be a longtime evolved member of the newly formed Circle City Rotary Club. Pam would serve on various other boards and/or committees which included the YMCA, Chamber of Commerce, and Four Cities Employer’s Advisory Council, etc. Pamela was a selfless person and had such a positive effect on so many lives. She was an amazing wife, mother and grandmother. She was friendly, loving, and gracious. She deeply enjoyed her family and friends. She loved to play games with her grandchildren. Time is all she ever wanted, and it is time that we will count down until we meet her again. Anyone who wishes to make a memorial donation in honor of Pam is asked to direct their gift to the City of Hope Hospital or the American Cancer Society.

View Full Obituary

Randall Paul Saeli Sr. - November 10, 1951 - March 31, 2024

Departed: 03/31/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: Randall Paul Saeli Senior, son of Sam and Ella Saeli, was a beloved husband, father, grandfather, and brother. He was born November 10, 1951 in Jamestown, New York and passed away March 31, 2024 at his home in Jurupa Valley, California. He is survived by his wife, DeAnn Saeli of 43 years, his children; Randall Jr. (Rita), Nicki (Robert) and Matt (Kayla), his grandchildren; Kaley, Camilla, Logan, Luke, Avery, Brooklyn, Archie, and Beau, and his two brothers; Mark and Lance Saeli. Randall Sr. was an Aerospace machinist for 20+ years and spent his free time coaching his childrens’ sports teams and providing the support they needed to be successful. Randall Sr. enjoyed taking his family on eventful, yearly vacations when his kids were young. In more recent years, he spent his time with family, attending his grandchildren’s activities and was an avid sports fan. A private family service will be held April 21, 2024 in honor of his memory.

Julia Verdusco Perez - August 20, 1932 - March 30, 2024

Departed: 03/30/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: Julia Verdusco Perez, age 91 of Corona, California, was born August 20, 1932 and went into the arms of Jesus on March 30, 2024. She was born Julia Verdusco in Corona, California and attended the Washington Elementary School on Grand Boulevard Corona. She married at a young age the love of her life Manuel Mendez Perez who preceded her in death. She is survived by four adult children, Marion Perez Perez, Manuel Perez, Norman Perez and Edward Perez, five brothers, Alex, David, Ray, Joe and Henry, ten grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Viewing and Rosary will be Thursday, April 11, 2024 from 4pm – 8pm at Thomas Miller Mortuary in Corona, California. Catholic Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10am Friday, April 12, 2024 at Saint Edward Catholic Church in Corona, California. Interment will follow at Sunnyslope Cemetery, Corona, California.

View Full Obituary

Antonio Galvez - September 04, 1959 - March 28, 2024

Departed: 03/28/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: Antonio “Tony” Gálvez Garduño, falleció el día jueves 28 de marzo a la edad de 64 años, en la ciudad de Corona, California. A su lado, estuvo su amada esposa Ernestina, quién fue testigo de la valentía y de la paz que tuvo al partir. En estos últimos 7 meses, afrontó con gran fortaleza su lucha contra el cáncer, y fue un gran ejemplo de que la vida, se vive con una gran sonrisa. A pesar del dolor y del sufrimiento, él siguió valiente y fuerte hasta el final. De joven dejó su querido México en busca "del sueño americano” y logró todas las metas que se propuso. Antonio conoció a su gran amor, Ernestina Martínez de la Cruz, en la Ciudad de México en el año 1979 y se casaron en 1981. Su matrimonio duró 43 años lleno de amor y apoyo entre ambos. Juntos formaron una gran familia con sus hijos José Antonio, Cecilia, Gustavo y Sandra. Antonio fue un querido hijo, hermano, esposo, papá, abuelo, cuñado, tio amigo, y consejero, y será honrado en una ceremonia tradicional acompañado de toda su familia y amigos. Mr. Antonio “Tony” Galvez Garduño passed away March 28th, 2024, at the age of 64 in the city of Corona, California. By his side was his loving wife, Ernestina Martinez, who was witness to his courageous effort and the peace he had when he passed. The last 7 months he fought with great resilience, cancer and could attest that life should be lived with a grand smile on one’s face. Even with great pain and suffering, he remained strong and courageous until the end. When he was young, he left his beloved Mexico in search for the “American dream”, and he was able to achieve all his goals and dreams. Mr. Antonio met the love of his life in 1979 and married her in 1981. Their marriage lasted 43 years and was filled with love and support of each other. Together they formed a family with their children José Antonio, Cecilia, Gustavo, and Sandra. Antonio was a loved son, brother, husband, father, grandfather, brother-in-law, uncle, friend, and mentor. He will be honored in a traditional celebration of life by his friends and family.

View Full Obituary

Betty Jean Panattoni - September 21, 1930 - March 28, 2024

Departed: 03/28/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: Betty Jean was born September 21, 1930, to James and Ruby Powers in Malden, Missouri and peacefully passed away March 28, 2024, at the age of 93. Betty’s parents moved their family of 6 girls to California in the 1940s. She graduated from Corona High School in Corona, CA in 1948. At the age of 17, she needed her father’s permission to marry her “true love”, David P. Panattoni. They did so on September 18th, 1948, in Corona, California where they also settled down and raised their 3 children. Betty lived in Corona until 2015 when she moved to Orange Park, Florida to live with her youngest daughter’s family until her passing. Betty worked at the Corona Daily Independent working with the paper boys. She also worked at Riverside General Hospital in the accounting department for many years. While David was alive, they spent many years camping and fishing in Baja, Mexico with family and friends. Baja was their true happy place! Betty and Dave volunteered many years at City of Hope in Duarte, CA fundraising for the cancer research center. They participated in helping with many fundraisers. Betty’s greatest joy was her family. She loved interacting with her children, grandchildren and her church in the children’s ministry, missions, and the seniors’ ministry. She loved God with her whole heart, body, and soul. She shared this love to whomever would listen! She is survived by her 3 children: Felicia Brannon of Orange Park, FL; Joe (Nancy) Panattoni of Oroville, CA; and Debby (Brian) Bryan of Orange Park, FL. She is the proud Nana to 6 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. She also loved dearly her many, many nieces and nephews. She was preceded in death by her beloved & devoted husband of 56 years, David P. Panattoni, who passed away in 2004. Betty was the last of the legendary, six-Powers girls to pass away, and she did so peacefully as her favorite song “His Eye is On the Sparrow” was sung and ushered her into Glory. More than anything else in this world, Betty wants everyone to know that Jesus loves them and desires greatly to see each and every one of her loved ones in Heaven. John 3:16 - For God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life. Betty’s Viewing will be held on Thursday, April 18th from 11:00am – 1:00pm at Thomas Miller Mortuary at 1118 E. 6th Street in Corona, CA 92879. Interment will follow at Riverside National Cemetery at 22495 Van Buren Blvd. in Riverside, CA 92518.

Susan Christine Avalos - January 01, 1947 - March 28, 2024

Departed: 03/28/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: Susan Christine Avalos (nee Martinez) was born on January 1, 1947, the first baby born in the Pomona Valley of that year. She died peacefully on March 28, 2024, surrounded by her family. Susan grew up in Chino, graduated from Chino High School in 1964 and attended Mt. San Antonio College. In 1969, Susan married Louis Avalos, and moved to Corona, where she raised her family and lived until her death. Susan worked for the Chino Unified School District at the district offices and Los Serranos Elementary School. She worked many more years for the Corona-Norco Unified School District and retired from Corona Fundamental Intermediate School. Always a faithful servant, she devoted time to her church as a catechist. Over the years Susan enjoyed needle crafts, oil painting, cooking, and spending time with family and friends. Susan is survived by her husband of nearly 55 years, Louis Avalos, her children Matthew Avalos (Teresa), and Sara Avalos Martin (Troy), her granddaughters Nicolette Spencer (Avalos), Brooke Avalos, and Scarlet Creighton. She will also be missed by her brothers Steven Martinez and Rod Martinez, her sisters Elissa Martinez San Juan and Regina Martinez-Keddy, her many nieces, nephews, brothers and sisters in-law, cousins, and friends. Susan was preceded in death by her grandson Brendan Avalos, her parents Leonardo “Lupe” and Christine Martinez, and her brother Leonard Martinez. Services will be at Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church, 3760 N. McKinley St., in Corona, on Thursday April 25, 2024, with the viewing from 12 to 1 p.m. Mass will follow from 1 to 2 p.m. Burial will be at 2:30 p.m. at Crestlawn Memorial Park, 11500 Arlington Ave., Riverside. Reception to follow at The Farm 379 North Dr, Norco, CA 92860

Gregory Bolick - January 14, 1963 - March 27, 2024

Departed: 03/27/2024 (Corona)

Obituary Preview: Greg was born in Ohio and lived in Akron before moving to California with his family. His intelligence was recognized from a young age, skipping a grade in elementary. He finished high school early by his sophomore year and joined the workforce. He was working recently as an OCTA paratransit driver for almost 12 years. Greg was vey caring and kind too all his passengers. They would give him fruit or snacks when he picked them up on his routes. Greg had 6 brothers and 1 sister Ray, Ron, Chuck, Larry, Jeff, Georgia, and Brad. Greg enjoyed music, Pink Floyd, Gensis, Phil Collins, and Cheap trick were among his favorite bands. His favorite types of music were blues and progressive rock. He played guitar and the keyboards. He also collected mini amps. Greg enjoyed anything computer related. He liked to play computer and Virtual Reality games. He built his own tabletop arcade gaming system using a raspberry pi. He loved to bbq and was a master at making tri tip. Plus he made some really great chili. He also enjoyed baking too, making breads and cookies. Halloween was his favorite holiday, he loved decorating the front yard and handing out candy in costume every year. He made some of his own props for Halloween. Greg was very handy and can fix anything. Greg also loved baseball and football, his favorite sports teams where the Cleveland Browns, Cleveland Indians and the Angels. He was married to Cindy for 20+ years. His favorite vacation trip was to Riveria Maya, Mexico. He loved to fish and loved and cherished all his pets past and present. He doted on Bella, Coco and Starlight who loved to always be with him. He is preceded in death by his Dad George, Mom Dorothy, and Brother Chuck. He is survived by his Brothers and Sister Ray, Ron, Larry, Jeff, Georgia and Brad, and his wife Cindy.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is an obituary?

An obituary is a written notice that announces the death of a person, typically including their name, age, date of birth and death, and other biographical information. It may also include details about their life, accomplishments, and surviving family members.

What is the purpose of an obituary?

The primary purpose of an obituary is to inform friends, family, and community members of a person's passing and to provide details about their funeral or memorial service. It also serves as a way to honor and celebrate the person's life.

Who writes an obituary?

Obituaries are typically written by family members or close friends of the deceased, although they can also be written by funeral homes or professional obituary writers.

What information should be included in an obituary?

A typical obituary includes the person's name, age, date of birth and death, place of residence, occupation, education, hobbies, achievements, and surviving family members. It may also include details about their funeral or memorial service.

How long should an obituary be?

The length of an obituary can vary depending on the publication or online platform. Generally, it should be concise and to the point, ranging from a few sentences to a few paragraphs.

Can I include photos in an obituary?

Yes, many publications and online platforms allow you to include one or more photos with the obituary. This can help personalize the tribute and make it more meaningful.

How do I submit an obituary to a newspaper or online platform?

You can usually submit an obituary through the newspaper's website or by contacting their obituary department directly. For online platforms, you can follow their submission guidelines and forms.

How much does it cost to publish an obituary?

The cost of publishing an obituary varies depending on the publication or online platform. Some newspapers offer free or low-cost options, while others may charge by the word or line.

Can I write my own obituary in advance?

Yes, it's becoming increasingly popular for people to write their own obituaries in advance. This can ensure that your life story is told in your own words and can be a therapeutic exercise.

What is a death notice?

A death notice is a brief announcement of a person's passing, typically including only their name, age, date of birth and death, and funeral service information. It's often used when a full obituary is not desired or possible.

What is the difference between a death notice and an obituary?

A death notice is a brief announcement of a person's passing, while an obituary is a longer, more detailed tribute that celebrates their life and achievements.

Can I include humor or anecdotes in an obituary?

Absolutely! Obituaries don't have to be somber or formal. Including humor or personal anecdotes can make the tribute more engaging and reflective of the person's personality.

How do I handle sensitive information in an obituary?

If there are sensitive issues or conflicts within the family, it's best to focus on the positive aspects of the person's life and avoid controversy. You may also consider consulting with other family members or a professional writer for guidance.

Can I include charitable donations or memorials in an obituary?

Yes, many people choose to include information about charitable donations or memorials in lieu of flowers. This can be a meaningful way to honor the person's legacy and support a good cause.

How long after the funeral should I wait before submitting an obituary?

You can submit an obituary at any time after the person's passing. However, it's common to wait until after the funeral or memorial service has taken place.

This depends on the publication or online platform. Some may allow edits or corrections, while others may not. Be sure to review your submission carefully before publishing.

What if I need to correct errors in an obituary?

If you notice errors in an already-published obituary, contact the publication or online platform immediately. They may be able to make corrections or issue a retraction.

Can I share an obituary on social media?

Absolutely! Sharing an obituary on social media can help spread the word and allow friends and family to pay their respects online.

How do I find old obituaries?

You can search online archives of newspapers or genealogy websites like Ancestry.com. Local libraries may also have archives of old newspapers that you can access.

Can I use an obituary as part of a eulogy or speech?

Yes! An obituary can serve as a great starting point for crafting a eulogy or speech. You can use it as inspiration and add your own personal anecdotes and memories.

What if I'm struggling to write an obituary due to grief?

If you're finding it difficult to write an obituary due to grief, consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member for support. You may also want to take some time to process your emotions before attempting to write.

Are there any specific guidelines for writing an obituary for a veteran?

If the deceased was a veteran, you may want to include information about their military service, awards, and honors. You can also contact local veterans' organizations for guidance on how to properly acknowledge their service.

Can I include quotes or lyrics in an obituary?

Absolutely! Including meaningful quotes or song lyrics can add depth and personality to the tribute. Just be sure to keep them relevant and respectful.

How do I ensure that my loved one's legacy lives on after they're gone?

In addition to writing a thoughtful obituary, consider creating a memorial fund, planting trees or flowers in their honor, or establishing a scholarship in their name. These gestures can help keep their memory alive for years to come.
